name: Nigella
climate: Nigella prefers temperate climates with cool spring and mild summer temperatures.
This plant can handle a range of temperatures but does not thrive in extreme heat or cold.
It is suitable for growing in regions with distinct seasonal variations in temperature.
Nigella is adaptable but performs best in areas with moderate humidity levels year-round.
sunlight: Nigella requires full sun to thrive and produce its characteristic flowers.
It can tolerate partial shade, but full exposure to sunlight is ideal for blooming.
For optimal growth, plant Nigella in an area that receives at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily.
The plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers if grown in too much shade.
watering: Nigella needs regular watering, especially during dry spells, to maintain moisture.
Be careful not to overwater, as Nigella prefers well-drained soil and can suffer if waterlogged.
During the growing season, consistent watering helps the plant to develop strong growth.
Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot.
soil: Nigella thrives in well-draining soil rich in organic matter for optimal growth.
Sandy or loamy soil types are preferred, as they provide the necessary drainage.
Avoid heavy clay soils that retain too much moisture, potentially harming the plant.
Neutral to slightly alkaline soil pH is ideal, though Nigella can tolerate a range of pH levels.
